title: Complete Service Guide
subtitle: Understanding Your Scores, Recommendations, and Service Options
audience: For Business Leaders, Marketers, and Decision Makers

content.text: Answer Engine Optimization (AEO) is how your content performs when AI-powered search engines like ChatGPT, Perplexity, and Google AI Overviews answer user questions. Unlike traditional SEO, where success means appearing in search results, AEO success means your content is actually cited as the answer.
This guide explains what each metric in the AEO Suite measures, why it matters, and how you can improve your visibility in AI-powered search results.
The Free tier analyzes a single web page and provides objective, measurable insights about how AI-friendly your content is. Think of it as a health check for one page at a time.

subsections.title: Pro Tier: Unlimited Analysis + Advanced Features

Professional services include comprehensive PDF reports with recommendations, actual implementation of changes to your website, and ongoing consultation. For Full AEO Implementation, you also receive a dedicated AEO consultant who works with your team throughout the engagement.
Every analysis produces scores from 0-100 for each analyzer. Here's how to interpret them:
Each analyzer has different maximum possible scores based on the number and weight of factors measured. Some analyzers max out at 100 points while others have components worth 25-40 points each.
Schema markup is structured data that tells AI engines what your content is about without having to guess. It's like adding labels to everything on your page.

items: Presence of any structured data (JSON-LD format)
Types of schema present (Article, Product, FAQPage, etc.)

content.text: AI engines rely heavily on schema markup because it provides explicit, machine-readable information. Pages with proper schema are much more likely to be cited because the AI doesn't have to interpret your content - you've told it exactly what everything is.

items: Add JSON-LD schema markup to your page <head> section
Include Article schema for blog posts and news content
Add FAQPage schema if you have Q&A content
Include Person or Organization schema with author.url for credibility

content.text: Crawlability determines whether AI engines are allowed to access and index your page. Without this, you won't show up in AI-powered search at all.

items: Meta robots tag (noindex blocks AI access)
Internal links (helps AI discover related content)

content.text: If your page has a "noindex" directive, AI engines won't include it in their knowledge base at all. This is the #1 reason pages don't appear in AI search results.

items: Include 3-5 contextual internal links to related pages

content.text: Proper HTML structure helps AI engines quickly understand your page topic and organization. Good structure = better comprehension = higher citation likelihood.
AI engines scan pages rapidly. Clear HTML structure with one H1 and logical H2/H3 subheadings helps them quickly understand your content organization and extract relevant information.

items: Use exactly one H1 tag for your main topic
Add H2 and H3 subheadings to organize content sections

content.text: This analyzer checks if AI search engines can properly access, understand, and parse your page structure. Think of it as the foundation - without this, nothing else matters.
Machine readability measures how easily AI models can process and understand your content. This is different from human readability - it focuses on content length, complexity, and structure.
The Flesch Reading Ease Score ranges from 0-100. It's calculated based on sentence length and syllables per word. Higher scores = easier to read.

items: Word count: 1,000+ words for comprehensive coverage

content.text: AI models process content more effectively when it's substantial (1000+ words) yet readable. Too short lacks depth; too complex reduces comprehension. The Flesch score helps ensure your content hits the sweet spot.

items: Expand thin content to at least 1,000 words
Break long sentences into shorter ones
Use simpler words where possible without losing meaning

content.text: Professional Services - Content Optimization: We rewrite existing content to improve machine readability while maintaining your brand voice and expertise. This includes breaking complex sentences, adding transition phrases, and restructuring paragraphs for optimal AI parsing.
AI engines love content structured as questions and answers because it directly matches how users search. This analyzer checks if your content follows natural Q&A patterns.

items: Question patterns (What is, How to, Why, When, Where, Who)
Clear answer patterns (questions followed by direct answers)

content.text: When users ask questions to AI search engines, the AI looks for content that already answers those questions directly. Content with clear Q&A structure is exponentially more likely to be cited.

items: Add an FAQ section to your page
Use questions as H2 or H3 headings
Provide direct, concise answers immediately after each question
Implement FAQPage schema markup for Q&A sections

content.text: Professional Services - Content Optimization: We analyze search query intent and transform your content into question-answer format that matches what users actually ask. This includes proper FAQPage schema implementation.
Factual density measures how much concrete, citable information your content contains. AI engines prefer dense, fact-rich content over general statements.

items: List items (bullet points and numbered lists)

content.text: AI engines are more confident citing content that includes specific data, organized lists, and references to authoritative sources. Vague statements are rarely cited; specific facts are.

items: Add specific numbers and percentages to support claims
Use bullet points and numbered lists for key information
Reference research and attribute information to sources
Replace general statements with specific data points

content.text: Professional Services - Content Optimization: We research and add relevant statistics, create structured lists, and source authoritative citations to dramatically increase your factual density score and AI citation potential.
This analyzer evaluates how your content is organized and whether it's optimized for AI comprehension. AI engines prefer content that is scannable, well-structured, and information-dense.
Experience signals show that the content creator has first-hand knowledge or direct experience with the topic. AI engines heavily favor content from people who have actually done or tested something.

items: Experience indicators - phrases showing first-hand experience
Media count - images, screenshots, charts showing evidence
Personal anecdotes about testing or implementation

content.text: Google's documentation explicitly states that AI Overviews prioritize content demonstrating first-hand experience. Generic advice ranks lower than "I tested this and here's what happened."

items: Add personal testing experiences and results
Include original photos or screenshots as proof
Use first-person language: "I tested", "We found", "In our experience"
Share specific outcomes from personal experience

content.text: Expertise signals demonstrate that the content creator has specialized knowledge, credentials, or qualifications in the topic area.

items: Person schema markup with author details

content.text: AI engines need to determine if the author is qualified to write about the topic. Medical advice from a doctor is weighted differently than from a blogger. Clear expertise signals build trust.

items: Add clear author bylines to all content
Implement Person schema with author.url and credentials
Mention relevant credentials in author bios or content
Include "years of experience" or specialization statements

content.text: Authoritativeness shows that your content is backed by research, links to credible sources, and is kept current. It's about being a reliable source of information.

items: Last updated date presence and recency

content.text: AI engines cross-reference information. Content that links to authoritative sources is seen as more reliable. Regular updates signal that the information is current and maintained.

items: Add article:modified_time meta tag when updating content
Use <time datetime=""> tags for publish/update dates

content.text: Trustworthiness signals show that your site is secure, transparent, and legitimate. These are basic credibility factors that all professional sites should have.

AI engines assess whether a site is trustworthy before citing it. No HTTPS = immediate red flag. Missing contact information or privacy policy suggests an unprofessional or potentially unreliable source.

items: CRITICAL: Enable HTTPS with SSL certificate
Add contact email or form links
Create and link to privacy policy
Link to terms of service if applicable

content.text: Page-level E-E-A-T only checks the specific page. For comprehensive E-E-A-T including About, Contact, and Author pages across your site, you need the Pro tier (up to 15 pages) or Professional Services (unlimited pages).

E-E-A-T stands for Experience, Expertise, Authoritativeness, and Trustworthiness. This analyzer evaluates signals on the specific page that establish credibility and authority. These factors are critical for Google AI Overviews and Perplexity.
Keyword presence checks where your target keywords appear on the page. Strategic placement in key locations signals relevance to AI engines.

Each keyword can earn up to 20 points based on where it appears. If you enter 3 keywords, the maximum is 60 points, which is then normalized to 40 points. This means strategic placement matters more than keyword quantity.

AI engines look for keywords in specific strategic locations. A keyword in your title and H1 carries much more weight than buried in paragraph 10. This analyzer shows you exactly where you're missing critical placements.

items: Include primary keyword in title tag
Use primary keyword in H1 heading
Use keyword naturally 3-5 times throughout content

content.text: Answer positioning checks if your content provides answers early in the page. AI engines prefer "front-loaded" answers - information that appears in the first 100 words.

items: Keyword appears in first 100 words - 15 points

content.text: What Counts as Direct Answer Patterns:

When users ask AI engines a question, they want immediate answers. Content that buries answers deep in the page performs poorly. AI engines scan the beginning first - if the answer isn't there, they may move to another source.

items: Answer the main query in the first 100 words
Provide a summary/key takeaway at the beginning

content.text: Semantic relevance checks if your content covers the topic comprehensively using related terms, variations, and contextual information.

items: Semantic variations (plurals, prefixes, related phrases) - 15 points

content.text: What Counts as Topical Depth Indicators:
Comprehensive coverage signals expertise. AI engines favor content that addresses a topic from multiple angles - benefits AND drawbacks, theory AND examples, overview AND detailed guide.

items: Use plural and singular variations naturally
Include sections on benefits and drawbacks
Add "how to" sections with step-by-step guidance
Cover different types or categories within the topic

content.text: Professional Services - Content Optimization: We perform query research to identify the actual phrases users search for, then optimize your content to match those queries precisely while covering all semantic variations.
This analyzer evaluates how well your content matches specific search queries or keywords. It only runs if you provide target keywords - otherwise you'll see "N/A" scores.

⚠️ Important:
 This analyzer requires you to input target keywords. Without keywords, all scores show as N/A.
Citation potential measures how many "citable sentences" your content contains - statements that AI engines can extract and quote directly.
AI engines need clear, extractable statements to cite. Long rambling paragraphs are hard to quote. Short, definitive statements with attribution are perfect for AI citations.

items: Share unique insights from your experience
Avoid vague statements - be specific and concrete

content.text: Structured answers use schema markup and HTML elements to explicitly organize information in AI-friendly formats.
Schema Types That Help AI Engines:

items: FAQPage: Marks questions and answers explicitly
At least 2 lists or 1 table for full points

content.text: Schema markup explicitly tells AI engines "this is a question" and "this is the answer". Without schema, AI must interpret HTML. With schema, everything is unambiguous. Lists and tables make information scannable and extractable.

items: Add FAQPage schema for any Q&A content
Implement HowTo schema for instructional content
Use bullet points for lists of items
Create tables for comparing data or options

content.text: AI accessibility measures how easily AI engines can identify and extract your main content from all the other elements on your page (navigation, sidebars, ads, etc.).

items: Having both clearly identifies your main content
90%+ of images have alt text: 7 points
50-89% of images have alt text: 4 points

content.text: Without semantic tags, AI engines must guess which content is main vs. navigation. With proper tags, they know exactly where to look. Heading hierarchy provides a content outline. Alt text describes images for AI understanding.

items: Wrap main content in <main> and <article> tags
Add viewport meta tag: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width">
Use exactly one H1, multiple H2s, and H3s as needed
Add descriptive alt="" attributes to all images

A: 80+ is excellent, 60-79 is good with room for improvement, 40-59 needs significant work, and below 40 indicates critical issues. Most sites start in the 40-60 range.
Q: Why does my Query Match show "N/A"?
A: Query Match requires you to input target keywords. Without keywords, this analyzer cannot calculate scores. Enter your target keywords when running an analysis to get Query Match results.
Q: Why is my Technical Foundation score low even though my page loads fine?

A: Technical Foundation primarily measures schema markup, not page speed. Most sites lack proper structured data, which is why scores are often low. The good news: adding schema is usually straightforward.
Q: What's the difference between Page-Level E-E-A-T and Site-Level E-E-A-T?

A: Page-level (Free tier) only checks the specific page analyzed. Site-level (Pro tier) checks your About, Contact, and Author pages across your entire site - these factors are especially important for Google AI Overviews and Perplexity.
Q: Can I upgrade from Free to Pro?
A: Yes! Upgrade anytime through the pricing modal. Your past analyses are preserved and you'll immediately get unlimited analyses, PDF exports, and site-level analysis.
Q: What's the difference between Pro ($20/month) and Professional Services (starting at $1,500)?

A: Pro gives you the tools to analyze and understand issues yourself. Professional Services means we actually fix the issues for you. Pro is self-service analysis; Professional Services is hands-on implementation by experts.
Q: Do I need Pro if I'm getting Professional Services?

A: Not necessarily. Professional Services include comprehensive analysis. However, many clients keep Pro for ongoing monitoring after implementation. The Monthly Retainer ($150) is designed for post-implementation maintenance.
Q: Can I implement the recommendations myself?

A: Absolutely! The Free and Pro tiers provide actionable recommendations with code examples. If you have technical resources (developers, SEO specialists), you can implement everything yourself. Professional Services are for when you lack resources or want expert implementation.
Q: How long does it take to see improvements after implementing recommendations?

A: Technical improvements (schema, HTML structure) can show impact within 2-4 weeks as AI engines re-crawl your site. Content improvements may take 1-2 months to fully reflect in AI citations. This varies by AI engine - Google AI Overviews typically respond faster than others.
Q: Which recommendations should I prioritize first?

A: Start with items marked "CRITICAL" in the recommendations. These typically include: removing noindex directives, adding schema markup, and ensuring proper title/H1 tags. After critical issues, work on E-E-A-T signals, then content structure improvements.
Q: Will this guarantee my content appears in AI search results?

A: No tool can guarantee AI citations. However, following these recommendations significantly increases your likelihood of being cited. AI engines use many factors beyond what any tool can measure (domain authority, user engagement, competitive landscape), but these optimizations give you the best possible foundation.
Q: Which AI engine does this optimize for?

A: All of them. While Google AI Overviews, Perplexity, and ChatGPT have some differences, they share core requirements: structured data, clear content, E-E-A-T signals, and machine readability. Our recommendations cover the universal factors that all AI engines value.
Q: How is this different from regular SEO?

A: Traditional SEO optimizes for appearing in search results listings. AEO optimizes for being cited as the answer by AI engines. The focus shifts from rankings to citations, from keywords to questions, and from backlinks to first-hand experience. Many traditional SEO practices still apply, but AEO adds new layers of optimization.
